Fig. 1 XRD patterns of strontium niobate samples prepared by a hydrothermal reaction at 473 K for 24 h with different molar ratio of Sr/Nb: (a) Sr/Nb = 0.5, (b) Sr/Nb = 1.0, (c) Sr/Nb = 1.5, (d) Sr/Nb = 2.0, (e) Sr/Nb = 2.5, and (f) Sr/Nb = 3.0. ♦: Sr2Nb2O7, ↓:SrNb2O6, ●:Nb2O5. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of strontium niobate samples prepared by a hydrothermal reaction at 473 K for 24 h with different molar ratio of Sr/Nb: (a) Sr/Nb = 0.5, (b) Sr/Nb = 1.0, (c) Sr/Nb = 1.5, (d) Sr/Nb = 2.0, (e) Sr/Nb = 2.5, and (f) Sr/Nb = 3.0. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Ammonia synthesis rate over 2 wt% Ru catalyst supported on strontium niobates prepared with different nominal molar ratio of Sr/Nb. Reaction conditions: prior to activity tests, the catalysts (100.0 mg) were reduced in a H2 flow of 15 mL min−1 at 573 K for 3 h; the activities were tested in 60 mL (STP) min−1 synthesis gas (3H2 + N2, 99.999%) at 673 K and 0.1 MPa. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) TEM image of 2 wt%Ru/2.0SrNb, (b) size distribution of Ru crystallites of 2 wt%Ru/2.0SrNb, the average Ru crystallite size (d) = 1.37 nm, standard deviation (σ) = 0.20 (c) TEM image of 4Ba-2 wt%Ru/2.0SrNb, and (d) TEM image of 8Cs-2 wt%Ru/2.0SrNb. Prior to TEM observations, the catalysts were reduced in synthesis gas (3H2 + N2, 60 mL (STP) min−1) at their corresponding optimal activation temperature: 573 K (2 wt%Ru/2.0SrNb), 773 K (4Ba-2 wt%Ru/2.0SrNb), and 673 K (8Cs-2 wt%Ru/2.0SrNb) for 3 h. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 NH3 synthesis rate over (a) 4Ba-2 wt%Ru/2.0SrNb and (b) 8Cs-2 wt%Ru/2.0SrNb as a function of time on stream. Reaction conditions: 100.0 mg catalyst, 60 mL (STP) min−1 synthesis gas (3H2 + N2), 673 K, 0.1 MPa. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XRD patterns of (a) 4Ba-2 wt%Ru/2.0SrNb and (b) 8Cs-2 wt%Ru/2.0SrNb measured at different phases: as-prepared (fresh), after activity tests (used), and after stability tests (aged). Reaction conditions: 100.0 mg catalyst, 60 mL (STP) min−1 synthesis gas (3H2 + N2), 0.1MPa. ♦: Sr2Nb2O7, ∇: Ba(NO3)2,↓: CsNO3, and ◊: CsOH. Table 8 Catalyst BET surface area (m2 g−1) Fresh Used Aged 4Ba-2 wt%Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 52 51 52 8Cs-2 wt%Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 26 29 31 Ammonia synthesis over Cs- or Ba-promoted ruthenium catalyst supported on strontium niobate Minxuan Chen a b Mingwei Yuan a b Jinjun Li a Zhixiong You a b ⁎ a School of Resources and Environmental Sciences, Wuhan University, Wuhan 430079, PR China School of Resources and Environmental Sciences Wuhan University Wuhan 430079 PR China b International Cooperation Base for Sustainable Utilization of Resources and Energy in Hubei Province, Wuhan 430072, PR China International Cooperation Base for Sustainable Utilization of Resources and Energy in Hubei Province Wuhan 430072 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Strontium niobates with different crystalline structure and morphology have been prepared via a hydrothermal method and applied as a support for ruthenium catalyst in ammonia synthesis. The sample synthesized with a nominal Sr/Nb = 2.0, having a pure Sr2Nb2O7 crystalline phase and specific surface area of 87 m2 g−1, exhibits the best performance as support for Ru catalyst. The flake-structured Sr2Nb2O7 substrate induced epitaxial growth of truncated pyramid shaped ruthenium nanoparticles with a dispersion as high as 93%, which have abundant steps and B5 sites playing a key role in ammonia synthesis catalysis. Adding Cs- or Ba-promoter enhanced the activity of Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalyst drastically. The highest ammonia synthesis rate over 8Cs- or 4Ba-2 wt%Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 was 4986 and 2317 (μmol g−1 cat h−1) at 0.1 MPa and 673 K, respectively. In addition, both catalysts were stable over reaction for 72 h at 673 K and 0.1 MPa. Thus, the synthesized Sr2Nb2O7 is expected to be a practically promising oxide support for ruthenium ammonia synthesis catalsyts. Keywords Ammonia synthesis Ruthenium catalysts Strontium niobate Cs-promotion Ba-promotion 1 Introduction Ammonia is an important commodity chemical manufactured globally at a scale of 170 million metric tons per year in 2016 [1]. So far, more than 80% of the synthesized ammonia is utilized to produce fertilizers for food crop’s growth [2]. Thus, ammonia synthesis is an effective artificial nitrogen-fixation technique, which supplies 40–60% of nitrogen source for human bodies [3]. Additionally, ammonia is recently attracting extensive research interests as a potential carrier for renewable energies or hydrogen due to its characteristics of (1) carbon-free, (2) high hydrogen content (17.8 wt %), (3) easy liquification (0.86 MPa at 293 K or 239.7 K at 0.1 MPa) and (4) mature technologies and infrastructures for production, transportation and storage [4–6]. Currently, ammonia is mainly synthesized from N2 and H2 via Haber-Bosch process using fused iron (Fe-Al2O3-K2O) catalysts. Since dinitrogen molecule has extremely high dissociation energy (945 kJ mol−1) [7,8] of its triple bond, the Haber-Bosch process must be operated at high temperatures (673–873 K) and high pressures (20–40 MPa) to achieve a reasonable performance [9,10]. Due to such stringent operational conditions, the Haber-Bosch synthesis becomes one of the most energy-intensive industrialized processes; it is estimated to consume approximately 1% of the world’s power production [11]. Moreover, the H2 feed of the present ammonia synthesis plants are mostly obtained from steam reforming of natural gas (one type of fossile resource), which is unsustainable and will be substituted by renewable H2 souceses, such as biomass gasification or water electrolysis (electricity is generated from renewable energies). These renewable low-pressure H2 sources are relatively dispersive, which demands catalysts that are more efficient to accelerate ammonia synthesis at milder reaction conditions. For these reasons, searching for noval catalysts that have reasonable performance at moderate reaction conditions is one of the key challenges for promoting the traditional Haber-Bosch process and for applying ammonia as a carrier for sustainable energies or hydrogen in the future. Ruthenium-based catalysts have been extensively investigated as the second-generation ammonia synthesis catalysts because they exhibit higher activity at mild reaction conditions and less sensitivity to NH3 concentration in gas phase as compared to the traditional fused iron catalysts [12–17]. Ru catalysts supported on high surface area graphite (HSAG) have been industrially applied in the KBR advanced ammonia synthesis process (KAAP) since 1992 [18]. However, carbon supports react readily with H2 to form methane at ammonia synthesis conditions in the presence of Ru. Methanation in this manner causes gradual degradation of the carbon support, limiting the lifetime of Ru/C catalyst [19–21]. It is thus still of importance to find a suitable oxide support for ruthenium catalyst. So far, a variety of metal oxides, such as MgO [22–27], Al2O3 [28–33],Co3O4 [15],barium hexaaluminate [13], zeolite [34–36], mayenite electride [37–40], Pr2O3 [17], CeO2 [41] and etc., have been proposed as supports for Ru ammonia synthesis catalysts. Among these oxides, magnesia, barium hexaaluminate, praseodymium oxide and electride are currently promising oxide supports for Ru catalysts due to their electronic and/or structural promotion to the activity of Ru nanoparticles for ammonia synthesis [13,17,37,42]. However, the high reactivity to H2O of MgO and electride inhibit their widespread use in industry. The rate-determing step in ammonia synthesis is dissociation of N2 molecules on the surface of Ru crystallites [29,43]. The dissociation rate has been reported to depend significantly on the morphology (size and shape) and electronic state of Ru crystallites, which can be modified by the supports and/or promoters [44,45]. Previous studies have proved that: (1) flat Ru crystallites epitaxially grown on layered substrates show better performance than round Ru particles because more abundant B5 sites can be found on the surface of the former [13,45,46]; and (2) compounds such as alkali, alkaline earth, or electrides that can donate electrons to Ru metal, resulting in a decreased ionization potential of Ru, thereby allowing electron transfers from the metal to the antibonding orbitals of the N atom and reducing the activation energy for the dissociative adsorption of N2 molecules [47]. Therefore, an ideal support for Ru catalysts should modify the shape and size of Ru crystallites to achieve abundant B5 sites on their surface and have ability to donate electron to Ru metallic atoms. Rencently, strontium niobates are widely investigated as photocatalyts because they have special optical, ferroelectric and piezoelectric properties [48–51]. It has been reported that the morphology of strontium niobates can be tailored by changing synthetic parameters during preparation [52]. Based on the previous knowledge, we expect that niobates with layered structure may influence the shape and size of Ru crystallites and thus work as promising supports for Ru catalysts. Herein, we demonstrate that Ba- or Cs-promoted Ru supported on Sr2Nb2O7 substrate exhibits superior activity and stablibity for ammonia synthesis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Sr2Nb2O7 support The Sr2Nb2O7 support was synthesized via a hydrothermal method. First, a precursor of niobium (Nb2O5·nH2O) was synthesized from NbCl5 via a hydrothermal method as previously reported work [53]. An alcohol solution of NbCl5 (0.37 mol L−1) was prepared by dissolving appropriate amount of NbCl5 (Aldrich, 99.0%) in ethanol (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, analytical purity). Then, the pH of the solution was adjusted to around 10.5 by adding 4 wt% NH4OH aqueous solution with stirring. After 4 h-stirring at room temperature, the mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and treated at 473 K for 24 h. Subsequently, the solid product was recovered by centrifugation at 8000 rpm for 30 min and washed repeatedly with distilled water until the filtrate was confirmed to be free of chloride anions using AgNO3. Finally, the product was dried at 353 K under a vacuum of around 1.0 KPa. Second, the resultant Nb2O5∙nH2O and Sr(OH)2∙8H2O (aldrich, 99.5%) with different molar ratio were mixed in 45 ml distilled water. After stiring for 30 min, the pH of supernatant was in the range of 12.85–13.50; the mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 473 K for 24 h. The resultant product was filtered, washed thoroughly with deionized water until the pH of the filtrate was nearly 7. The product was dried in vacuum (∼ 1.0 KPa) at 353 K for 10 h. 2.2 Preparation of supported Ru catalyst Ruthenium catalysts were prepared by impregnation method. The dried Sr2Nb2O7 samples were ground with an agate morta and pestle, and dispersed in a tetrahydrofuran (THF) solution of Ru3(CO)12 (Aldrich, 99.0%) with stirring at room temperature for 12 h. Then the solvent was removed using a rotary evaporator (313 K, 10 KPa). The dried samples were treated in an Ar (99.999%) flow of 5 mL min−1 at 723 K for 3 h. The catalysts obtained had a nominal Ru loading of 2 wt%. The Cs- or Ba-promoted Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalysts were prepared by impregating the treated Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 samples in an aqueous solution of CsNO3 or Ba(NO3)2, respectively. 2.3 Ammonia synthesis The dried catalyst samples were gound, pelletized, crushed and sieved. The fractions from 220 to 450 μm were collected and loaded into a quartz tubular reactor (I.D. = 7 mm). Before activity measurements, the catalysts were treated in a H2 (99.999%) flow at 573–873 K for 3 h to reduce ruthenium cations to metallic state and to decompose CsNO3 or Ba(NO3)2. The catalytic activities were measured in a synthesis gas (H2/N2 = 3/1, 99.999%) flow of 60 mL (STP) min−1 over 0.10 g sample. The reaction temperature was varied from 573 to 773 K at 0.1 MPa. The produced ammonia was absorbed by a 1 × 10−3 mol L−1 solution of sulfuric acid, and the rate of ammonia formation was determined from the decreasing rate in the conductivity of the sulfuric acid solution for measurement after a 30-min stabilization at appropriate reaction conditions. 2.4 Characterization The crystalline structure of the samples was analyzed by a X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique performed on a PANalytical X’Pert Pro diffractometer equipped with a Cu-Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5405 Å). All diffraction patterns were recorded in a 2θ range of 10–70◦ at a scan speed of 2◦/min. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm data collected at 77.3 K using an automatic specific surface area/pore size distribution measurement apparatus (BELSORPmini II, BEL, Japan) was applied for evaluating Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of the prepared samples. Pior to analysis, the samples were degassed at 473 K under 10−2 KPa for 2 h. The specific surface areas were calculated from the linear part of the BET plot where P/P0 ratios are 0.05–0.25. The content of Nb and Sr in the products were measured by an inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrum (ICP-AES, IRIS Intrepid II XSP, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA). The morphology of the synthesized Sr2Nb2O7 samples was observed on a Zeiss Sigma scanning electron microscopy (SEM) at an acceleration voltage of 20 kV. The images of Ru nanocrystallites on the supports were recorded on a transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100, JEOL, Japan) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The acidity of the supports was evaluated by a temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of ammonia technique carried on a laboratoray-made flow system connected to a gas chromatograph (GC) (GC-2020, Trustworthy, China) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Before the desorption test, the catalyst (100.0 mg) was pretreated in a N2 (99.999%) flow of 15 mL min−1 at 773 K for 3 h, then cooled to 373 K, and finally exposed to a flow of 5 vol% NH3 (balanced by 99.999% N2) of 10 mL min−1 for 30 min, to allow the sample to reach adsorption equilibrium. The physically adsorbed ammonia molecules were then removed by purging the catalyst with a N2 (99.999%) flow of 15 mL min−1 at 373 K for 30 min. In the desorption test, the catalyst was heated from 373 to 1073 K at 10 K min−1, and the desorbed ammonia was carried in N2 flow (15 mL min−1) into the GC for quantification. The density of exposed Ru atoms on the catalysts was determined by a H2-pulse titration method performed at 323 K assuming chemisorption stoichiometry of H:Ru = 1:1 [25,54]. Before measurements, the catalyst (100.0 mg) was first reduced in a H2 (99.999%) flow of 45 mL min−1 at 573 − 823 K for 3 h, and then kept at the same temperature under a Ar (99.999%) flow of 15 mL min−1 for 1 h to remove the adsorbed H atoms on reduced samples. After cooling to 323 K under Ar, H2-pluse measurements were performed by repeatedly injecting 1.0 mL of 5 vol% H2 in N2 (one pulse) until a constant TCD signal was achieved. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of Sr/Nb molar ratio on the morphology of strontium niobate samples Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the synthesized strontium niobate samples. Obviously, the molar ratio of Sr(OH)2/Nb2O5 play a key role in the formation of crystalline structure of the obtained materials. When equal amount of Sr(OH)2 and Nb2O5 (Sr/Nb = 0.5) was mixed and hydrothermally treated, SrNb2O6, Nb2O5 and Sr2Nb2O7 phases (Fig. 1a) were observed in the sample. Raising the Sr/Nb to 1.0, we obtained a sample containing mainly orthorhombic Sr2Nb2O7 phase (PDF#70-0114), the other two phases disappeared (Fig. 1b). Further increasing the Sr/Nb to a value above 1.0, no obvious change in the crystalline structure of the samples was observed (Fig. 1c–f). This result appears to demonstrate that the added Sr(OH)2 exceeding the stoichiometry of Sr2Nb2O7 has little effect on the crystalline structure of the resultant strontium niobates. To confirm the XRD results, we hydrothermally treated appropriate amount of synthesized niobates in a mixture of equal volume of 36% hydrochloric acid and of 30% hydrogen peroxide aqueous solution at 453 K for 10 h to obtain a clear solution for ICP measurements. The ICP results (Table 1 ) reveal that the measured Sr/Nb values agree well with the nominal Sr/Nb (calculated with the added amount of Sr and Nb precursors during synthesis) when they are lower than 1.0. On the other hand, the measured Sr/Nb values for all the niobate samples prepared with a nominal Sr/Nb > 1.0 are close to 1.0, which explains why all the samples prepared with nominal Sr/Nb ≥ 1.0 displays the same XRD pattern. These results suggest that the excessively added Sr(OH)2 was lost during the filtrating and water-washing process after hydrothermal treatment. Corresponding to their crystalline structures, the textural properties of the samples chareacterized by BET specific surface area (Table 1) and SEM (Fig. 2 ) shows a similar trend. The sample prepared with a nominal Sr/Nb = 0.5, having a relatively small surface area of 11 m2 g−1, was composed of elongated crystalline grains in size of ∼200 × 1000 nm (Fig. 2a). Increasing the addition amount of Sr(OH)2 to Sr/Nb ≥ 1.0, we obtained large aggrates comprising of Sr2Nb2O7 flakes. The size of the flakes decreases slightly with increasing in the nominal Sr/Nb, in accordance with the varying in BET surface area. These results imply that the excessively added Sr(OH)2 accelerates the nucleation rate of niobates in hydrothermal synthesis; as a result, aggregates of smaller flakes are formed. 3.2 Catalytic activity of Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 Fig. 3 compares the ammonia synthesis rates over 2 wt% Ru catalysts supported on strontium niobates synthesized with different nominal molar ratio of Sr/Nb at 673 K and 0.1 MPa. The activity increases with increasing in the added amount of Sr(OH)2 of the surports when the nominal Sr/Nb ≤ 2.0. The 2 wt%Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalyst prepared with a nominal Sr/Nb = 2.0 gives the highest activity of 239 μ m o l g cat -1 h -1 . Further raising the nominal Sr/Nb to values above 2.0 decreased the activity slightly (Fig. 3). Therefore, we choosed Sr2Nb2O7 prepared at Sr/Nb = 2.0 as the support for Ru catalysts to study the effect of promoters. 3.3 Catalytic activity of Ba- or Cs-promoted Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 Addition of Ba- or Cs-promoter lowered the BET surface area of the catalysts from 83 to 32 and 15 m2 g−1, respectively (as shown in Table 2 ). The promotion effect of barium and cesium is compared in Table 2. For both Ba- or Cs-Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalysts, the ammonia synthesis rate increased first and then decreased with increasing in the addition amount of promoters. The optimal molar ratio of Ba or Cs promoter to Ru is 4 or 8, respectively. The highest activity over 4Ba- or 8Cs-2 wt%Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 at 673 K and 0.1 MPa was 1279 or 4170 μ m o l g cat -1 h -1 , which was 5 or 17 times larger than that of the unpromoted catalyst. Tables 3 and 4 list the ammonia synthesis rates over 4Ba- and 8Cs-2 wt%Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 activated in synthesis gas (3H2 + N2) flow at different temperatures for 3 h. As one can see, raising the activation temperature first enhanced and then lowered the ammonia synthesis rate of both catalysts. The corresponding optimal activation temperature was 773 and 673 K for Ba- and Cs-promoted catalysts, respectively. Two phenomena may occur during the activation process: One is the decomposition of Ba(NO3)2 or CsNO3 to their oxide and/or hydroxide form; the other is the formation and growth of Ru particles. When the catalysts are activated at low temperatures, the promoter’s nitrate precursor may not decompose completely; on the other hand, as the activation temperature is high, the Ru particles may sinter to some extent. The fraction of exposed Ru atoms on the catalysts was measured by H2-pulse titration method (Table 5 ). It is clearly seen from Table 5 that the Ru particles on the unpromoted samples activated at 573 K was significantly dispersed (D = 92.9%), and the calculated average size was 1.4 nm using the method described by Borodziński et al. [55]. The morphology of the 2 wt% Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalyst reduced in synthesis gas (3H2 + N2, 60 mL (STP) min−1) at 573 K for 3 h was observed by TEM (Fig. 4 a). Ru crystallites are uniformly deposited on the Sr2Nb2O7 substrate. The size of more than 500 Ru crystallites shows a monomodal distribution with an average size (d) of 1.37 nm and a standard deviation (σ) of 0.20 (Fig. 4b). This result confirms that the high dispersion of Ru crystallites obtained via H2-pulse titration method is reasonable and spillover of hydrogen atom to the support is ignorable. The lattice spacing of the Sr2Nb2O7 substrate (Fig. 4a) is 0.275, 0.277, and 0.283 nm, corresponding to the (002) and (151) planes of the orthorhombic Sr2Nb2O7 crystallites (Fig. s1). From the XRD pattern of Sr2Nb2O7 synthesized with a nominal Sr/Nb = 2.0 as shown in Fig. s1, one can see that the (002) and (151) peaks are the top two most intensive diffractions, suggesting that they are the preferentially exposed facets of the Sr2Nb2O7 flakes. These exposed facets composed of oxygen anions can induce the epitaxial growth of Ru crsytallites [56] in a manner similar to the hexagonally close-packed carbon atoms of graphite reported by Song et al. [45] and to the mirror planes of barium hexaaluminates as reported by You et al. [13]. Given the nearest-neighbor atom distances on the Ru (001) surfaces (0.271 nm) and on the (002) (0.285 nm) or (151) (0.278 nm) planes of Sr2Nb2O7, the mismatch of the Ru (001) lattice with respect to the oxygen lattice on (002) or (151) planes is 4.9% or 2.5%, respectively. Such a small mismatch facilitates the epitaxial growth of ruthenium nanocrystallites with high dispersion on Sr2Nb2O7 substrate. Activating the catalyst at higher temperatures (673 and 773 K) lowered the dispersion to 72.8% and 62.1%, corresponding to an average size of 1.8 and 2.1 nm, respectively (Table 5). These results are in good agreement with the values calculated from TEM observations (Fig. s2c, d). The Ru nanoparticles epitaxially grown on Sr2Nb2O7 substrate are flat in a height of 1–2 (reduced at 673 K, Fig. s2a) and 2–3 nm (reduced at 773K, Fig. s2c). The section of Ru particles projected normal to the exposed facets of Sr2Nb2O7 substrate are trapezium-shaped, these side facets of the flat Ru nanoparticles are composed of steps, having more abundant B5 sites than that for round particles. This peculiar shape of Ru particles must contribute to the high performance of the Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalysts as that observed for Ru/barium hexaaluminate [13] and Ru/graphite [45]. Ru particels abruptly grew from 2.1 to 11.6 nm when the 2 wt%Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalyst was activated at 873 K for 3 h. Addition of Ba- or Cs-promoters to the Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 system reduced the H2 uptake significantly (Table 5). It implies that the number of exposed Ru atoms are very small at 323 K. The low H2-uptake can be caused by two reasons: One is Ru particles sintered drastically as Ba- or Cs-promoter was added; the other is Ru particles are covered by Ba- or Cs-promoters at H2-pulse measurement conditions. Based on the H2-uptake values, we can calculate the average size of Ru particles on 4Ba- and 8Cs-Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalysts to be 24.3 and 90.8 nm, which were not observed with TEM (Fig.4c&d). Thus, the coverage of Ru particles by Ba- or Cs-promoter at 323 K should be the reason why the H2-uptake was low for promoted catalysts. Similar phenomena have been oberserved by other research groups [13,57]. TEM results (Fig. 4b and c) also support the deduction that the Ru particles were covered by Ba- or Cs-promoters at room temperature because we could find a few particles, which had comparable size to those on the unpromoted catalyst. These Ru particles became exposed to the reactants at ammonia synthesis conditions. Consequently, we chose the dispersion values of unpromoted catalyst to calculate the turn over frequency (TOF) of Ba- or Cs-promoted catalysts (Table 6 ). The obtained results are considered reasonable because it has been reported that the dispersion of Ru nanoparticles are maintained on the addition of promoters when the catalysts are reduced at mild conditions [19,57,58]. The acidity of oxide support is known to be detrimental to the activity of Ru catalysts for ammonia synthesis. The surface acidity of Sr2Nb2O7, Nb2O5, γ-Al2O3 and MgO determined by TPD of ammonia is shown in Fig. s3, and the amount of chemisorbed ammonia on these supports is given in Table s1. The adsorbed ammonia amount by specific surface area of oxides follows the sequence of γ-Al2O3 >> Nb2O5 > MgO > Sr2Nb2O7. The acid strength of the oxides, reflected by the desorption temperatures, was also very different. The ammonia molecules bound on Sr2Nb2O7 desorbed at 400–700 K with the main peak top at around 520 K. The ammonia TPD profile of MgO over similar temperature range splitted into two main peaks located at about 490 and 630 K. This result suggests that the acid sites are weaker on Sr2Nb2O7 than on MgO. γ-Al2O3 and Nb2O5 desorbed ammonia over a wide temperature range (400–1075 K), indicating that the two oxides had high density of strong acid sites. These strong acid sites on Nb2O5 should be the reason why 2 wt%Ru/Nb2O5 catalysts shows poor activity for ammonia synthesis (Table s2). Table 7 compares the catalytic performance of Ba- or Cs-Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalyst with that of Ru catalyst supported on other substrates. Due to the different Ru-loading, we calculate the ammonia synthesis rates based on Ru weight. One can see that Ba- or Cs-promoted Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalyst exhibits a distinguished activity for ammonia synthesis, which is 10% higher than that of Cs-Ru/MgO, and 10 times higher than that of Ba-Ru/AC (industrialized catalyst). Although the mayenite electride supported Ru catalyst showed a comparable activity to our catalysts, the synthesis and reduction of mayenite electride are slightly difficult, and the electride slowly degrades by water vapor and oxygen in air. 3.4 Catalytic stability of Ba- or Cs-Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 Stability is another factor that should be considered as important as activity for practical catalysts. The ammonia synthesis rate over Ba-Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 and Cs-Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 measured at 673 K and 0.1 MPa for 72 h time on stream is shown in Fig. 5 a and b. Obviously, no deactivation was found for the two catalysts, suggesting the catalysts were stable. After stability tests, the corresponding surface area of the aged Ba-Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 and Cs-Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 was 52 and 31 m2 g −1, which was slightly larger than that of the fresh and used samples (Table 8 ). It suggests that the textural morphology of the catalysts is stable under ammonia synthesis conditions. Fig. 6 presents the XRD patterns of the Ba- or Cs-Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalyst at three different phases: as-prepared (fresh), after 5-h activity tests (used) and after 72-h stability test (aged). The crystalline phase of Ba(NO3)2 (Fig. 6a) and CsNO3 (Fig. 6b) was found in the fresh catalysts. After activity tests, no Ba containing phases were detected by XRD, suggesting the barium promoter existed in amorphous or well-dispersed state; on the other hand, the CsNO3 promoter was converted to CsOH. During the 72-h time on stream tests, the crystalline structure of Sr2Nb2O7 substrate showed no obvious change; but a minor reduction in the crystalline degree of the supports was observed, in accordance with the slight increase in specific surface area of the aged catalysts (Table 8). 4 Conclusions Strontium niobates with a large surface area was prepared using hydrothermal method and examined as support for Ru catalyst for ammonia synthesis. The Ba- or Cs-promoted Ru catalyst supported on Sr2Nb2O7 synthesized with nominal Sr/Nb = 2.0 showed superior catalytic activity and stability for ammonia synthesis than Cs-Ru/MgO, which was considered as one of the most ative oxide support at present. The exposed (002) and (151) facets of Sr2Nb2O7 substrate induced the epitaxial growth of Ru nanocrystallites in truncated pyramid shape with abundant steps and B5 sites, which played a key role in catalysis of ammonia synthesis. Thus, strontium niobate can be a practically promising potential candidate for Ru ammonia synthesis catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Strontium niobates with different crystalline structure and morphology have been prepared via a hydrothermal method and applied as a support for ruthenium catalyst in ammonia synthesis. The sample synthesized with a nominal Sr/Nb = 2.0, having a pure Sr2Nb2O7 crystalline phase and specific surface area of 87 m2 g−1, exhibits the best performance as support for Ru catalyst. The flake-structured Sr2Nb2O7 substrate induced epitaxial growth of truncated pyramid shaped ruthenium nanoparticles with a dispersion as high as 93%, which have abundant steps and B5 sites playing a key role in ammonia synthesis catalysis. Adding Cs- or Ba-promoter enhanced the activity of Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 catalyst drastically. The highest ammonia synthesis rate over 8Cs- or 4Ba-2 wt%Ru/Sr2Nb2O7 was 4986 and 2317 (μmol g−1 cat h−1) at 0.1 MPa and 673 K, respectively. In addition, both catalysts were stable over reaction for 72 h at 673 K and 0.1 MPa. Thus, the synthesized Sr2Nb2O7 is expected to be a practically promising oxide support for ruthenium ammonia synthesis catalsyts.
coredata.dc:title: Ammonia synthesis over Cs- or Ba-promoted ruthenium catalyst supported on strontium niobate
